posts.cooked: Might be an interesting feature because it enhances your privacy a bit.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked: Why not make an audio call then?

You want a video call but don’t want to share too much of your surroundings. If you are delivering a lesson online, or having a business meeting, you’ll want to be seen without your house being in view as well - then family members can come and go behind you (for example) and your house can remain private.
They can do that, but it’ll cost you another few hundred megabytes in ML libraries.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked: Probably not - the library to find your head is already i it, so now you’ll have not to blur the head but everything else. But doing that not for static images but for video, real-time on phone hardware might be stretching the cpu (and battery consumption) to the limit. Or beyond on (some? most? all?) current phone hardware.

The library to detect faces is there, but not even to contour the blur to the face, just to detect and draw a square over it. And background blurring involves more than just not blurring the face – you need the entire foreground: face, body, any held items, etc.

It would definitely have an impact on battery use, but it can be done.
Totally support this feature. In my company everyone uses it now in Microsoft Teams when he‘s in home office.
I may be wrong (can’t remember if I actually used my phone with Teams), but I think Teams does this on phones already, so the hardware should be able to take it.

I think this would be mostly useful for desktop where you answer calls on your desk.

It’s a minor feature but still useful one and especially one that enhanced privacy, so I wanted to make sure it’s mentioned here.

posts.name: Brochard
posts.cooked: Yeah, I think the blur functionality could be expended, permanent toggle of auto blur, remove blur, photo/video/call real time face/background blur

posts.name: Stephen Hartley
posts.cooked: I’d like the ability to be able to use custom image files jpg/png etc to use as a virtual background for video calls - this is already a feature of zoom, MS Teams etc

posts.name: Steven
posts.cooked: You need to do semantic segmentation. This is a much harder problem than facial detection. Do you happen to know what ML libraries Signal uses? Maybe this is something I could help with since I’m studying vision, though I’m studying other problems. If we could quickly roll these into Signal it might give us a competitive advantage over other messengers. This would go beyond feature parity.

That would be interesting as well as quite processor intensive and expensive in terms of battery power.
Maybe the desktop version could be a good candidate, but as we all know it is quite far from feature parity with the phone apps and doesn’t provide any image editing/blurring/recognition function.

Android app appears to now use the Android system built in FaceDetector.
This is the commit where they removed the Firebase version

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android

Replace Firebase ML vision with built in face detection.

committed 11:44PM - 28 Jan 21 UTC
alan-signal
+120 -127

while the iOS app seems to use the Apple Vision framework (look for VNFaceObservation in this large commit)

posts.name: Andy
posts.cooked: In the context of being secure, video calls with the ability to replace the background would be a great feature. With or without a chroma key screen would be a great addition to the app’s features.

posts.name: guentherwerner
posts.cooked: The topic has 482 views so it’s not a small topic, find it shocking that there are people who mainly use messangers like Skype because it offers this feature. In my opinion it provides some privacy because you can’t automatically infer your location. Everyone should be able to decide for themselves if they want to use this feature or not. Also whether it needs more processing power or data volume I find secondary here. Maybe you want to video call with friends or family and they want to see you in person and the living room does not matter so you do not have to send it through the network. I would use this function and I am certainly not the only one.

I want to present 2 hacky solutions for desktop users:

  1. List item
    If you are not on a budget, you can use a mirrorless camera with a big aperture (say f1.6), wide angle lens as a “webcam” by connecting the HDMI out of the camera to the computer using an Elgato Camlink. That will also get you a nicely blurred background.
    I do this, and a lot of people do a double take whenever I enter a zoom call. Best commment so far was “What is happening? Are you in a movie?”. Show HN: BokehCamera – Blur webcam background photorealistically using RealSense | Hacker News

  2. List item
    You can use this to create a virtual camera and then select it in Signal desktop
    GitHub - dheera/bokeh-camera

link_counts.title: Show HN: BokehCamera – Blur webcam background photorealistically using RealSense | Hacker News

posts.cooked:
Like many chat applications such as Google Meets, Microsoft Teams, and Zoom, it would be great if there’s a built-in feature to blur my background or replace the background with a photo while I’m on a video call.

As a bonus, it would be cool if zoom levels can also be adjusted like Logitech Capture software.

I used to use Logitech Capture to achieve this, but they’ve decommissioned the app and do not offer support for Apple Silicon. I do video calls with friends from time to time via Signal and it would be a great bonus to have this feature available in the signal app so I can do away with all the 3rd party software like OBS with background filter plugin which I can’t seem to get working either.

I assume a general goal would be have feature/setting parity across platforms, but would this seem an acceptable split for the Desktop version? I have begun using it a professional capacity for meetings and really miss the ability to blur - mostly so others don’t see my messy office. but it also removes “whatever” distraction might be occurring or seen in my background.

In my experience, most mobile callers to any meeting platform don’t have or use blurring anyway (while driving etc).

It seems from discussion above, avoiding the hardware impact of the libraries on mobile devices is likely a reasonable argument against doing this cross-platform… besides it’s much easier to sit up against a wall or other non-busy backdrop when on a mobile device so it seems less “needed” on mobile in my opinion.

posts.name: Luc Rochefort
posts.cooked: As far as I am concerned, if it can do it on Desktop, it would be great.

posts.name: Johan Vromans
posts.cooked:
Experience with other tools has taught me that blurring the background often results in annoying artifacts around the edges, especially if the person has curly hair. Very distracting.
If you want to hide the background it is easier and more pleasant to the eye to put a small projection screen behind your chair.
